Posts.Content: I had FEC-T which finished February 2016. I had endured awful joint pain during chemo but it continued after it had finished. 6 weeks after the end of chemo my GP offered me an X-ray which he called me to advise I now had moderate osteoarthritis in both hips and severe osteoarthritis in left knee and 'spiky bits' on shin. I was told to use crutches which I had been given the previous week by physiotherapists at hospital when I went in for my double mastectomy. What I can say is that 3 weeks after my mastectomy I started swimming (May 2016) this has helped enormously with my pain in leg joints/hips. I go 3-4 times per week swimming 24-30 lengths of 25 metres pool. Highly recommend swimming!!! I hope you can find relief xx
Posts.Title: 5 months post chemo - terrible, debillitating joint pain. Is it normal...

Posts.Content: How you describe the pain is almost identical to mine, I get severe ache/pain in upper thighs, hips, knees and upper arms. This started when I was on docetaxel chemotherapy - I had 3 cycles starting on 19th October 2015, I am due to have my final cycle of EC this Thursday (first FEC gave me heart failure so F removed from subsequent cycles) Today I went out with my mum and really struggled with walking and standing still is agony in my hips and lower back...like you another day might not be too bad. I have been told that once all my chemo is finished and it starts to go out my system it should improve - I have enrolled for a chemo fitness 6 week program in the hope it will get me moving and have bought a cycle you do sitting in a chair and can place on stable and use for your arms - yet to get started Haven't had any tests etc so pinning everything on it being chemotherapy related st present
Posts.Title: Pain in joints and muscles

Posts.Content: I sympathise with you and the worry you are going through. I was diagnosed with triple negative / invasive ductal cancer in August 2015, had lumpectomy (top outer quadrant of right breast) and sentinel node biopsy 10th September and healed well.  Start of October I noticed sudden onset of thick orange peel skin on lower half of breast, inverted nipple, red hot skin on one side. This was ultra sounded on 2 occasions and found to be 8 MM. Thick. My breast surgeon both times gave diagnosis of oedema caused by the surgery.  As my chemo is going to be finishing end of next month and I will then be due to go into radiotherapy I have had discussions with oncologist who is concerned about the effects of radiotherapy on oedema on a large breast.  This was discussed at multi disciplinary team meeting and the outcome was that as this 'oedema' has been there for 3months and hasn't altered it should be further investigated to rule out any inflammatory cancer. Biopsies taken last Wednesday and I get results next week (20th) ive been on chemo for the whole time this has been present and even if this did turn out to be IBC chemo would be the first treatment so I'm not concerned.... Just be good to have a definitive answer.
Posts.Title: Any one got experience of inflammatory breast cancer

Posts.Content: Absolutely I will!  Do you find it gets in your way when trying to lie on either side? I can't bring my arms to my side easily as I have these large buffers!  The morning after my bilateral mastectomy in April 2016 I was told I could have revision surgery no question but at my first follow up appt in August the surgeon was happy to do it but he advised that the rules had changed and he now had to apply for funding as it wasn't automatic anymore. Fortunately it was approved  Let you know how it goes  Bedford69
Posts.Title: Dog ear revision surgery under local anaesthetic

Posts.Content: Dog Ear revision surgery under local anaesthetic  Update. Went in for day surgery last Thursday feeling really calm and looking forward to the outcome.  Met with surgeon on arrival who marked me up and on further inspection decided he would revise the whole mastectomy scar line, extending it to deal with side bulge. As I had residual tissue in the right breast he also removed that resulting in my right breast now matching the flatness of my left. Local anaesthetic was given throughout the marked scar line and operation was commenced with a privacy screen put up so I couldn't see the operation... but sadly I felt it!...had to call out several times due to the pain experienced and more local was added each time but it was the most difficult experience I have had. A kg of flesh was removed during the operation. I was closed with 60-70 staples.  Saw the surgeon the next day and we are still friends! But I have advised that I couldn't consider doing the left breast in the same manner and will need general anaesthetic.  I do have to say I am really pleased with the result so far, looking forward to having staples out, very bruised at present.
Posts.Title: Dog ear revision surgery under local anaesthetic

Posts.Content: Well here I am giving an update 11 days after my second dog ear scar line revision surgery.  If you read the thread you'll know that my first experience on the right breast took place on 1.12.16 and wasn't a good experience as the local anaesthetic wasn't sufficient and I experienced pain throughout the op - the results however were amazing! From have a b cup spare boob under my armpit which made it difficult to put my arm down or sleep on that side I now have a lovely flat look but with enough flesh to allow for movement.  So after a meeting with breast surgeon to discuss having the left side done to match I was relieved the first thing he said was "neither of us want a repeat of last time", we talked and he advised that this time I would have local & sedation with canula in and anaesthetist monitoring throughout "just in case"... this worked out so much better!!! this time he didn't put a drain in as he hadn't taken as much flesh out but on Saturday 10 days after i 'sprung a leak! Bloody water from a seroma oozed out through staple no3 hole!! 3 clean bras and tops in an hour! Finally got some thick pads from chemist and after 2 hours the dripping stopped... and the pressure behind the scar line eased.  Got a bit of a square cornered boob which on wound check day 6 he said he would trim in clinic with some local - I did say I didn't want to be sponge bob squareboob!!! would I recommend dog ear revision- absolutel!! I felt really uncomfortable with the dog ear bumpers and now feel normal
Posts.Title: Dog ear revision surgery under local anaesthetic

Posts.Content: I only had the right one done and had one drain. I told the surgeon the next day when he asked if we were still friends! "Yes but there is no way I can consider having the other side done with just a local, not at the moment"  I am thrilled with the results of the dog ear but it's currently shades of yellow and purple and the 60-70 staples are prickling like mad!  Op on Thursday pm, out of hospital Friday pm and at dinner & dance Xmas do Saturday night! (Though no dancing just a spectator) lots of tightness and pulling which will need a bit of time. Back at surgeon tomorrow for wound check and to get histology report on flesh taken out and confirmation as to whether I had a neuroma which may have caused the pain in the operation which wasn't expected.
Posts.Title: Dog ear revision surgery under local anaesthetic

Posts.Content: Well done on your coffee morning I held one at home on Thursday 28th September and we managed to raise £265:00 - so chuffed. I did the coffee morning to give back for the support I received from McMillan when I went through breast cancer x
Posts.Title: Macmillan coffee day

Posts.Content: Hi all 2 days till my first dog ear revision surgery and was just wondering if anyone out there had had this procedure and under local anaesthetic? How long was your op? (Been told 1.5 hrs) much pain after? Did you have a drain at all?  Any info gratefully received Bedford69
Posts.Title: Dog ear revision surgery under local anaesthetic

Posts.Content: Hi Raspo I was very large chested (52H) and subsequently had large bulge on each side. It is really uncomfortable generally as I cannot bring my arms down straight without squashing it which is uncomfortable/painful. I also am a side sleeper but this is impossible without using my v shaped pillow to lift me and let bulge sit between v otherwise you are squashing it with body weight.  It was also noted that it was causing interrupted sleep as it would wake me up if I did lean on it... and they put in the letter to finance about the effects of lack of sleep when I am still recovering from big surgery.  I hit the swimming pool 3 weeks after my mastectomy going on average 3-4 times per week and swimming 2 miles per week, using breaststroke I have really exercised my upper body and I got rid of the fat bulge that started in my back and came round so the bulge under the arm is now not down to excess fat but left over breast tissue which would have been pulled forward if I still had breasts.  Does that help? Sorry if I waffled
Posts.Title: Dog ear revision surgery under local anaesthetic

Posts.Content: I had double mastectomy in April 2016 and on 1st December 2016 I had a total scar line revision and removal of further tissue on right breast to remove large bulge under arm. Wound was closed with 60-70 staples.  7 days after surgery the wound was weeping and was inflamed, I went to see gp practice nurse and was prescribed 7 day course of flucloxacillan which did the trick.  Staples out this Thursday and healing well and good cosmetic outcome to bulge
Posts.Title: what is the best Antibiotic for wound infection after mastectomy....

Posts.Content: Hi Raspo I will definitely keep you all informed how it goes.  If you have fat bulges at the side/underarm although technically it is your body fat it would have been pulled forward and flat by your breast when it was there so it is a direct result of the mastectomy- it apparently used to be automatic that as it was the result of cancer it could be treated surgically but now has to be applied for/justified as to why you want/need it.  Having a little 'tidy up' at the cleavage end also as currently have a square corner mini boob on the right lol - going to be posh tomorrow night! Well in 10 days lol Bedford69
Posts.Title: Dog ear revision surgery under local anaesthetic

Posts.Content: I had bilateral mastectomy Apr 16 (going from 52H bust and a boob loving hubby) to flat chested with b/c cup dogears under each armpit! Absolutely love being flat but hated dog ears. Right breast full scar line revision Dec 16 and left breast full scar line revision Mar 30 2017 - loving being flat! It's taken 15 months but hubby has finally shown me he accepts me looking the way I am. I was happy immediately after op and have never wavered. It feels good knowing he accepts it too
Posts.Title: Just had another mastectomy without reconstruction. Anyone else decided...

Posts.Content: I had bilateral mastectomy Apr 16 (going from 52H bust and a boob loving hubby) to flat chested with b/c cup dogears under each armpit! Absolutely love being flat but hated dog ears. Right breast full scar line revision Dec 16 and left breast full scar line revision Mar 30 2017 - loving being flat! It's taken 15 months but hubby has finally shown me he accepts me looking the way I am. I was happy immediately after op and have never wavered. It feels good knowing he accepts it too
Posts.Title: Just had another mastectomy without reconstruction. Anyone else decided...

Posts.Content: Hi Fluff99 Firstly congratulations on getting through your treatment- it's no mean feat as we know.  I know exactly how you feel as I recognise everything you said from my experience 6 months ago. My BRCA results turned out to be negative (much to everyone's surprise) although they did say that although I don't have BRCA genes I clearly have a genetic link.  I have a wonderful relationship with the McMillan Coordinator at our cancer treatment unit and she picked up I'd lost my raging positivity and having completed a questionnaire she referred me to the McMillan counsellor- a wonderful lady who has taken me on a journey equipping me with 'tools' to deal with those constant thoughts of reoccurrence I was having and took me to a place where I feel I can move on.  I would advocate for you putting yourself forward for counselling- if they do not feel it is the right time they will work with that and arrange when to see you. It was such a worthwhile experience- you deserve support after what you've been through so far but you are still on the journey xxx Good luck Bedford69
Posts.Title: Moving on, counselling?

Posts.Content: Good on you - let us know how you get on.
Posts.Title: Moving on, counselling?

Posts.Content: I can't speak for Zumba as never done it, but I had double mastectomy of very large breasts in April with no reconstruction, I started swimming daily 3 weeks after the mastectomy and it helped enormously!!! My tightness in chest eased within 10 days, never had any problems with armpit, cording etc cardio strength has improved and losing weight and toning up bingo wings  all non weightbearing which helps with my hips and knees which have been diagnosed osteoarthritic since the chemotherapy  more gentle on the joints but effective just a thought good luck
Posts.Title: Exercising after treatment

Posts.Content: I had TFEC chemotherapy and my oncologist said it was likely to come out 14 days after the first infusion and it was spot on!  It came o over a couple of days and I only had to shake my head and it would come out all over my top, if I touched my fringe it just fell out so I contacted my hairdresser and she blitzed it off and I emerged with turban and matching scarf which became my trademark- matching my turban/scarf combos to my outfit Once it's done it's done! I embraced the opportunity to splurge on scarves and wear my wig for special occasions  My hair started coming back after my 3rd EC infusion Feb 2016 and by July I was in 2nd haircut & highlights!! Love and keeping the shorter style All the best xxx
Posts.Title: Curious about when my hair will fall out.

Posts.Content: hi Raspo99 i can't offer any advice I'm afraid but wanted to say thanks for your thread of conversation as I too had bilateral mastectomy in April 2016, was given a pair of softees which I have used twice to help fill a dress for special occasioN. I have embraced being flat (in reality probably an A cup)  having read your thread and having tried the softees I may look into NHS prosthesis.  Can I ask did you have 'dog ears' excess tissue/skin at side of boobage after mastectomy? I gave and they are a pain. Surgeon agreed to revision surgery to 'tidy' them up but now it's gone to funding to agree
Posts.Title: Protheses problems?

Posts.Content: I am currently under the lymphodema clinic (since June) where I have had weekly/fortnightly massage and kinesio taping to move the fluid from the dog ear.
Posts.Title: Protheses problems?

Posts.Content: Hi Fiona i had similar experience. I had grade 3 invasive ductal cancer diagnosed in Aug 2015. Lumpectomy, T-FEC chemotherapy and then double mastectomy in April 2016.  I had the mastectomy due to inflammation in the skin which my oncologist said meant I couldn't have The radiotherapy and a right breast mastectomy was suggested instead. I was sent to the plastic surgeon to see if he could do a left breast reduction so that the prosthesis wouldn't have to be so big but he said no, and I was advised that under the NICE guidelines I didn't qualify for reconstruction  afterdiscussion and considering my family history it was agreed to do doublue mastectomy which I love!! Was large breasted and now I am complmerely flat and love it!!  I swim 4 days a week and feel amazing... going to look into prosthesis in the new year...for special occasions Take your time in decision making, consider all options and talk to people who have had the different options.  Have a a great Christmas  Bedford69
Posts.Title: I'm not allowed reconstructive surgery because my BMI is to high

Posts.Content: Hi Dolina i have been through similar. Had triple negative grade 3 IDCancer lumpectom, chemotherapy and double mastectomy all very positively and bubbly and then hit the wall  my worry is around it coming back. I lost my mum to triple beg cancer when she was 33yrs old (I was 12) she had breast cancer it came back within 17mths as brain tumour and then lung cancer and she was gone.  I already suffer from intercranial hypertension and have had horrendous daily headaches since Feb when Chemo finished - I've had CT scan and I know it's nothing sinister but you can't help but worry for the future.  I hate that I am like this as its not me!!! I am a really bubbly positive person and that's not helping bug my McMillan coordi is bri and picked up on my change and has got me a McMillan counsellor who I am working with which is great.  It is good to talk with people who understand  good luck xxx
Posts.Title: Now the treatment is over

Posts.Content: Mistymoley you bet right! Came away feeling totally un reassured  and that my family history counts for nothing and is something "I need to get over and maybe I would benefit from psychological help" ... Not my words!!! but heyho... They will be there for me if it does reoccur ... So nothing to worry about lets get on with life.  Bedford 69
Posts.Title: Now the treatment is over

Posts.Content: Hello Ali73 oh gosh I know how you feel!!! i had triple negative cancer (invasive ductal grade 3) had lumpectomy/chemo TFEC and then double mastectomy in April 2016, I too have unsightly dog ears! Which get in the way and prevent me sleeping on my side.  I was told due to the triple neg status and family history ( mum died aged 33 of recurring breast cancer - brain tumour/lung cancer) I would be offered 3 monthly check ups i was seen by breast care nurse who simply asked me how I felt , checked my scar line then booked me in for 6 months! I was asked if there was anything else and I mentioned the dogears which the surgeo had said the morning after surgery he could revise and I was advised after she went to speak to him (he never came to see me) that he was happy to do it BUT that surgery isn't automatically funded anymore and will have to go to panel for approval.  Do speak up and let them know any concerns you have, I was quite awkward as I explained that I wasn't really feeling reassured as the examination on the scar only highlighted that I didn't know what was normal for me anymore so how am I going to identify what is different!! i am seeing a McMillan counsellor which is great and I would recommend this if you can good luck xx
Posts.Title: Now the treatment is over

Posts.Content: Hi Helen oh don't be mislead I am grabbing life and running with it!! 3 weeks after a double mastectomy I started my new regime to live a healthier life, hit the swimming pool which I do now daily (between 4-6 times a week and have even got hubby joining on a sunday morning!) I had a belated 50th birthday/"I kicked cancers butt party" end of July and celebrated with 50 great friends and family who have been supportive and this Saturday hubby and I are off on our first ever cruise - can't wait :) I am being very positive, having fun with friends and family, working with dietitian to lose weight (long way to go), swimming to improve fitness and doing all I can to get in as good a shape as a can to prevent reoccurrence... it was just hard to have a follow up which as in your words seemed a bit of a waste of time, and came at the anniversary of the cancer being diagnosed and losing my mum - guess these things catch you unawares sometimes. but I've moved on, accepted that is what it is, and .... ive got a cruise to pack for... life ain't too bad is it, lol Bedford69
Posts.Title: Now the treatment is over

Posts.Content: Have wonderful time I got the all clear on breast cancer 2 weeks ago following lumpectomy, T-FEC chemo and double mastectomy 5 weeks ago...went out last Tuesday and booked cruise to Norwegian Fjords in August...can't wait, it's nice to have something to look forward to
Posts.Title: Just saying hello ....

Posts.Content: Phone and talk to someone at Macmillan or download their booklets, they have a couple on your rights at work and cancer and being off work... Very very good
Posts.Title: Worried sick

Posts.Content: KI am 5 weeks post surgery for bilateral mastectomy and feel great! Started swimming this week and going daily doing 20 lengths. Part of my get healthy regime!!!  I was very large breasted 52h!! So it's quite a change to be flat (no reconstruction) but I love it!! And have no plans at present to even use my prosthesis bras that I'd purchased in preparation. I am currently just wearing my zip up front fastening stretch bra vest tops more for the 'dog ear' flesh that you get left with at the side under arm than for mini boob support. My biggest thing is trying to find a swimsuit to fit but I'm getting there.  I do feel really well and have a real sense of 'it's over now' I feel I'm moving on.  I wish you all the love and luck in the world for your operation, be kind to yourself and let others be kind to you too xxx
Posts.Title: Post surgery bra 30F/30FF - where to find one?

Posts.Content: www.bettyandbelle.co.uk/30f-mastectomy-bras-861-c.asp www.sadiethebralady.com/mastectomy.asp Nicola jane are really good as well, really helpful staff when you ring
Posts.Title: Post surgery bra 30F/30FF - where to find one?

Posts.Content: Hiya I had to have my drain removed on my right breast on day 3 as the tube was coming out of the breast and was risk of infection and so I ended up with a seroma of fluid, I was closed up with staples for my surgery and they had to remove some staples to drain the seroma and this delayed the wound healing and I eventually had the wound cauterised with silver nitrate but all good.  I started driving at 4 weeks, unfortunately much movement before this caused my open wounds to bleed so had been avoided but once cauterised we were away!! The bras I am wearing are fab!!! The link is attached www.ambrosewilson.com/.../show.action Just ordered myself another set! They are so comfortable and will accommodate from an A-Ccup with the stretch and bargain price After the op when I had dressings on it was nice to put this bra on and just feel a little bit more secure Swimming - I was far from fit!! I self referred to dietitian when I went for my lumpectomy last September, wasn't allowed to lose throughout my chemo but now just starting my weight loss regime which is going to be as big a battle as the cancer!! Almost half my body weight to lose.  There is something really therapeutic about swimming though. I seem to go through so many thoughts whilst I'm in the pool and plan things and come out feeling good about myself for having done it. The chemo has given me osteoarthritis in both hips and knee so walking is painful and again the non weightbearing in the water is bliss - and after months of insomnia I have just had 2 full nights of uninterrupted sleep!
Posts.Title: Post surgery bra 30F/30FF - where to find one?

Posts.Content: I get copied in on all letters going from hospital to other professionals but I don't get get copied in on the letters from the GP
Posts.Title: Hospital letters

Posts.Content: Hiya i was a very large 52J bust and was refused a reconstruction due to high BMI following a double mastectomy in April 2016.  Dont regret it at all - I absolutely love being flat!! But I know my hubby misses boobs Dont feel rushed into making a decision either way if you can help it, and ask hubby to be honest about his feelings  Good luck xxx
Posts.Title: Advice Please....Reconstruction or Not??

Posts.Content: Oh my gosh I totally get you!!  I was a size 32 when I came in for my double mastectomy on Tuesday! 2 boobs off with a combined weight of 10 kg I am now 1 stone 8 1lbs lighter!! One size fits all paper pants is a load of rubbish so I was organised and purchased my own via www.thebigbloomerscompany.co.uk/DISPOSABLE-PANTIES.html Been in for 3 ops and done the trick!! Mind at rest and one less thing to worry about
Posts.Title: Having a meltdown

Posts.Content: Hi Ronstar i was originally due to have right beast mastectomy but combination of large breasts (52H) meant problems with balance and heavy prosthesi and reconstruction was not an option also given my family history of breast cancer and the fact it was triple negative it was agreed to have a double mastectomy- and I love it!!!!! 3 weeks after op I hit the swimming pool and began a new health regim as part of the new me and I now swim 4-6 days a week and feel great!!!  I love that I can fit in any clothes and don't have gaping buttonholes lol Mine was a 7 1/2 operation but I was up and about the next morning right as rain and apart from a bit of fluid retention when one of the drains had to be removed as it was starting to come out it was plain sailing.  Wouldnt want reconstruction as its not going to be my boobs back with the same feeling so not interested. love the freedom I feel now. Only thing is I can see my belly now!!! Lots of work to do now to rid that too...lol goid luck in whatever choice you make xx
Posts.Title: is double mastectomy easier than prosthesis 24/7

Posts.Content: I bought a chillow pillow as well after someone recommended them on here... £9.99 on Amazon.co.uk it has been absolutely brilliant!!!
Posts.Title: Feeling hot and cold at night

Posts.Content: I got one too and sent an email to moderators advising bloomin cheek!  Bedford69
Posts.Title: Friend request

Posts.Content: Bilateral mastectomy went ahead on 19th April though not quite as planned. Due to high BMI it was planned I would have two surgeons performing surgery to keep the theatre/anaesthesia time down to 2.5 - 3hrs but ended up with just my breast cancer surgeon doing it and a 6hr surgery. All went well.  One drain in each breast but the right breast drain had to be removed day 2 as the tube had begun to migrate out of the body, it was still draining 150ml per day so that formed in breast as a seroma. Seroma manually drained by surgeon removing a couple of staples and massaging breast and relieving the fluid on day 6 but it filled up again and when they tried again on Friday 29th (day 10) using needle to aspirate it was too thick...leaving breast care nurse no option but to leave it.  Discussed at multi disciplinary team meeting Friday afternoon where they were discussing the results of histology from mastectomy samples and my pathway for follow up treatment plan. Got a call to come in and meet with consultant Tuesday morning
Posts.Title: Double mastectomy, no reconstruction, advice welcome!

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed in August 2015 with invasive ductal breast cancer grade 3. Tumour very aggressive growing 1cm in 3 week period before lumpectomy surgery. My cancer was diagnosed as triple negative. Underwent T-FEC chemotherapy 6 cycles, finished Feb. Referred for genetic testing for BRCA 1&2, results was negative much to everyones surprise (my mum died aged 33 when I was 12, she had breast cancer, returned in a year as brain tumour and then lung cancer - we believe she was TNBC, I also lost my grandma to breast cancer so quite an emotional subject) Underwent T-FEC chemotherapy 6 cycles, finished Feb. Referred for genetic testing for BRCA 1&2, results was negative much to everyones surprise (my mum died aged 33 when I was 12, she had breast cancer, returned in a year as brain tumour and then lung cancer - we believe she was TNBC, I also lost my grandma to breast cancer so quite an emotional subject) Due to issues following lumpectomy inc oedema and seroma in right breast and the fact that I am very large breasted my oncologist has said that I am unable to have radiotherapy as the dosages I would have to have are too much. After much discussion with surgeons/plastic surgeons and multi disciplinary team meetings it was agreed on that I am going to proceed with a double mastectomy on 19th April. My question is... How long were people off for a double mastectomy without reconstruction ? How soon were you driving? How long did you have drains in? (I am a large band and H cup bra size!! So big job!!) Any info /advice you can give gratefully received
Posts.Title: Double mastectomy, no reconstruction, advice welcome!

Posts.Content: Had had my portocath removed 7th March ahead of my double mastectomy on 19th April. I have a hard lump under the scar where the port was.
Posts.Title: portacath scar tissue or a recurrence

Posts.Content: I'm afraid I don't have answers either... I had T-FEC chemotherapy from October 15 - Feb 16 and suffered severe joint pain with the Taxotere chemo which first infusionwasnt medicated, 2nd infusion I had tramadols and on 3 rd infusion was given oromorph  i was told that hopefully it will disappear once the chemo is finished - it didn't!  After 3 months I saw my gp who organised X-rays and rang me at home to advise I now had "moderate osteoarthritis in both hips, severe osteoarthritis in knees and 'spiky bits on tibia... whatever that is" I was put straight onto crutches to take weight off the joints. I had double mastectomy in April 16 and 3 weeks later in May I hit the pool - I swim 4 days per week and by August I had ditched the crutches and now just use a stick on bad days. I was prescribed tramadol to deal with the pain which I take when it gets bad and I can't get comfortable no matter what I do.  I am going to the gp on Tuesday to discuss this... will let you know if I get anywhere  bedford69
Posts.Title: Joint Pain

Posts.Content: I'm afraid I don't have answers either... I had T-FEC chemotherapy from October 15 - Feb 16 and suffered severe joint pain with the Taxotere chemo which first infusionwasnt medicated, 2nd infusion I had tramadols and on 3 rd infusion was given oromorph  i was told that hopefully it will disappear once the chemo is finished - it didn't!  After 3 months I saw my gp who organised X-rays and rang me at home to advise I now had "moderate osteoarthritis in both hips, severe osteoarthritis in knees and 'spiky bits on tibia... whatever that is" I was put straight onto crutches to take weight off the joints. I had double mastectomy in April 16 and 3 weeks later in May I hit the pool - I swim 4 days per week and by August I had ditched the crutches and now just use a stick on bad days. I was prescribed tramadol to deal with the pain which I take when it gets bad and I can't get comfortable no matter what I do.  I am going to the gp on Tuesday to discuss this... will let you know if I get anywhere  bedford69
Posts.Title: Joint Pain

Posts.Content: Hi Lujay I had grade 3 invasive ductal cancer. Lumpectomy, T-FEC chemotherapy and double mastectomy (April 2016).  Told I would be having 3 monthly checks due to diagnosis and treatment and family history. Had first checkup Aug 2016 and told come back in 6 months! Just an informal talk with breast care nurse no blood tests or scans.
Posts.Title: Whats the normal follow up after treatment finishes.

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed August 2015 with triple negative, grade 3 invasive ductal cancer.  I was referred for genetic testing at Northwick Park hospital testing for the BRCA 1 & 2 gene.  My mum died aged 33 from mestastic breast cancer. My maternal grandmother also died of breast cancer. I had no other female relatives on my mothers side.  The results were negative for BRCA but the letter/conversation was that I clearly had a genetic condition but they are currently the only ones they have a test for. My blood is being held for further tests that become available  Good luck
Posts.Title: Hereditary breast cancer

Posts.Content: I was originally having T-FEC (3 cycles of Taxotere and 3 cycles of FEC) started on the FEC 22.12.15 and had heart failure due to the 'F' component 5 fluorouracil - I recovered quickly and the 5 fluorouracil was removed for my next 2 cycles.  Whilst on EC I had no problems whatsoever apart from my fingernails getting beaus lines ridges on them and splitting but manageable. I had no sickness or any other side effects I had been warned about... It was easy Finished my last chemo this Thursday 11.2.16. My hair came out with the Taxotere but actually started growing back when I moved on to "EC" just awaiting multi disciplinary team decision on double mastectomy
Posts.Title: starting epurubicin & cycophosomide chemo

Posts.Content: Interesting reading... I was told I wouldn’t be offered reconstruction because my BMI didn’t meet NICE guidelines for reconstruction- I then went on to have 2 full mastectomy revisions in effort to flatten me out more evenly. The guidelines say reconstruction should be offered to ALL women. This would have made a difference to me
Posts.Title: NICE draft guidelines on treatment of primary breast cancer

Posts.Content: Thank you for sharing your experience - I was the same no pain in hip until after chemotherapy.  I get PIP payments but will have to go for review assessment in about 12 mths - not looking forward to it.  Bedford69
Posts.Title: Capability to work intwrview

Posts.Content: I love Cliniques dramatically different moisturiser, I have Rosacea which gives me severe red and dry flaky skin and this moisturiser is very good. I agree that chemo helped enormously with my complexion but a bit of a dramatic course of treatment for good skin
Posts.Title: Looking for a good light (thin) Moisturiser ?

Posts.Content: Hi Amanda sounds very familiar, I went through T-FEC 6 sessions Oct 2015-Feb2017 i found I had the incredible joint pain which start 36hrs after infusion and lasted 3-5 days before easing off. I have to say that for me recovery from these side effects was less each cycle but tramadol helped! On the 3rd cycle my oncologist prescribed me oromorph for those few really difficult days.  Just keep in mind it's doing its job and for a positive outcome and I hope you get through this period as painfree as possible xxx have a good Christmas x
Posts.Title: Docetaxel Side Effects

Posts.Content: Oh bless you Davityrose x  i too worked full time as the co-ordinator supporting students with autism across three college sites! Full-time and more as I used to take students out in the evening to improve social skills... absolutely loved it but knew that physically I couldn't keep up with the role and was fortunate that my son who runs his own business offered me a job working part-time in the office in my garden just in the mornings- this is perfect as on good days I swim in the afternoon and bad days I sleep! hard to get this through to assessor that I love what I do now... but I loved my full time job before and if it wasn't for the chemotherapy I would be back there doing it
Posts.Title: Capability to work intwrview

Posts.Content: hi Dayityrose i would like to chat with you in regards to your underactive thyroid and arthritis in knee.  I was diagnosed with underactive thyroid in Dec 2013 Aug 2015 0 diagnosed with breast cancer - lumpectomy, T-FEC chemotherapy and double mastectomy. April 2016 - diagnosed with moderate osteoarthritis in both hips and severe in left knee and spiky bits on my tibia. I am REALLY struggling with the pain in my hips and now in back - yesterday was given a whole body bone scan following my breast clinic checkup. They cant keep my thyroid in the 'normal' range so it has been upped and upped and now on 200mg daily. what is your experience?  sorry for going off at a tangent from original thread of messages Bedford69
Posts.Title: Capability to work intwrview

Posts.Content: I had 5 attempts on PICC line before they aborted and had portacath fitted under local instead.  I had to have 2/6 chemo infusions through veins the second of which leaked Life was a lot simpler after portacath fitted.  Good luck for the future treatments x
Posts.Title: PICC line aborted
